review_title: Wonderful Employer - Staff Morale Could be Better
pros: The non-exempt employee compensation at Colgate is exemplary and the benefits to the employee as well as the employee's family are spectacular. In general, Colgate is a pleasant place to work and the location is beautiful. The University is family oriented and very supportive of any personal issues that may occur outside of work and are willing to make accommodations for employees who may need to take time for illness for children or themselves or a family member. It is a diverse campus that makes it a point to live up to the word "diverse" and is accepting of all people. It is a wonderful place to be employed.
cons: Right now morale on campus for some employees seems to be a bit low.  This may be due to stress and changes occurring across campus over the past few years. However, this is a common with change and should even out after things settle down.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Hamilton, NY
pros: Beautiful campus with talented students
cons: Very small and conservative community. Students can be very entitled

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: very good place to study
cons: Not much diversity here at all

pros: gorgeous campus and great professors and amenities
cons: terrible administration that cares more about pr than the student body

pros: After Colgate, any job will look like a dream job.
cons: IT workers, beware. Colgate projects an atmosphere of progressive values and experienced contributors working together. The reality is, if you're not a manager, you're just a piece of meat, and you'll constantly be reminded how fortunate you are to work there. You are not there to serve customers or help people. You are there to make your manager look competent. There is a deeply embedded mid-level administrative back-scratching chain at Colgate, which has kept most staff at the level of indentured servitude for the last decade. The budget process is completely opaque, so you will have to ask repeatedly for the standard tools to do your job, and you will be expected to justify their need. (Nevertheless there is always money when IT managers want to throw themselves a party.) Campus infrastructure is a wreck, and network security is non-existent, but this provides plenty of high-profile "fire-fighting" jobs so that managers look like they are saving the world. IT management hates the faculty, so don't get caught doing faculty any favors. Your annual review process will probably be completed behind your back with no opportunity to participate or respond. Don't even think about complaining to HR, as HR is a major part of the problem, and defend their long history of bad decisions with lies and threats. And people wonder why higher education is in trouble.

review_title: Colgate was a toxic place to work
pros:
+ Benefits for full-time employees
+ Strong endowment and finances
+ Kind, caring co-workers
cons:
- The staff is overworked and under appreciated. There is high burnout and turnover leaving unfilled positions, which put additional stress on the people who stay.
- Colgate aims to champion diversity, equity, and inclusion. This does not come across in its treatment of staff at all. Staff positions were the first to be cut during the pandemic in an inhumane and uncaring fashion. Not all staff are protected by a union at this time. It is a predominately white institution, so staff of color often struggle to find meaningful support. It is difficult for staff with disabilities as well. Some old buildings still do not have adequate access. The administration is reluctant to agree to accommodations. 
- There is rampant elitism and entitlement not just from the privileged students, but from parents, alumni, faculty, and administrators.
- There is little mobility for talented staff. Many younger, high performing staff leave to advance their careers elsewhere. 
- The campus is very remote. The nearest city is 45 minutes–1 hour away. There's little to do in Hamilton, NY.

job_title: Academic Administrative Assistant in Hamilton, NY
pros: Benefits as wonderful at Colgate.
cons: When I left....I had spent the last two years of my 13 years of employment fighting to keep my job.  After much thought, it dawned on me that after watching events across the campus the HR Department and Administration, in my opionion, were slowly removing the employees that were making above average pay and who had much more vacation time on the books, all to bring in new employees that would accept less money and vacation time, therefore helping the bottom line.  In 13 years at CU, I NEVER had a bad review,  Yet I was terminated based on lies and half truths while out on Medical leave that was due to the stress of the job that I was doing.

pros: You will not get rich working in Acadamia but you can make a respectable salary and a long term career out of it.  There are many opportunities to obtain new skill sets and to venture off a little in side projects.  No micromanagement in my department, you are really kind of on your own to make or break your career here.  Comfortable work environment.  Many training opportunities.  Good benefits  A relaxed work place.  There is really is no room for advancement except for moving up to a senior ???, it is a title upgrade and a nice salary bump.  Usually 4%-6% annual raises.
cons: Lots of meetings and committees.  Lots of politics and internal issues amongst departments. You'll have to concede your creative nature and individual styles as everything is done by committee.  The process of getting decisions made is very slow and frustrating at times.  No one wants to commit to making the final decsion or take responsibility for it.

pros:
I loved the campus and the whole college atmosphere. I was (and still am) connected to the college, attending various sporting events. If you've ever worked on a college campus, you'll see some crazy things. It's one of the big reasons why I stayed so long

One of the biggest pros for any looking for full time work there is the tuition assistance for kids of those who work there, which I believe Is for any university your kid is looking to attend.
cons:
If you're a professor, you're paid well. As part of the support staff? not so much.That's played a role in why there are so many jobs which have unions. The interview process is a bit overboard as well. I had to interview with a committee of 5 or so people, than the head of the department for a job that paid a little more than what people at Wal-Mart made. 

Like most any job, there's pros and cons. It wasn't a bad gig for a part time job, and I enjoyed my time there.

review_title: Stepford Wives W/O children Please Apply
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The benefits seemed nice and the campus is lovely
cons: The pay is quite low for the expectations demanded of an Administrative Assistant. Prepare to work hard to get hired because the two-hour long interview with 20 different people can be a job in itself. Note* if you have a child, this is a strike against you. Note* If you don't fit the "Colgate Mold" you will not survive here. Colgate strives to have its departments filled with Stepford Robots free of thought. They want someone to learn the job in a week and never question their rule. The Kings and Queens of this University AKA faculty will never accept administration as anything more than menial serfs. Unless you can be exactly who they want you to be you will be made fun of behind your back, yelled at, taken advantage of, and finally worked until near-death...then terminated. The benefits sounded nice. If you do get a job here keep your thoughts and your personality to yourself. Remember that nobody is your friend. Very liberal in beliefs obviously, but they don't encourage you to think liberally outside of their beliefs.

pros: Colgate pays very well for the area, allowing even junior faculty members to live at the top of the local income spectrum.  If, like me, you've had your fill of loud, crowded cities, it's a really wonderful, beautiful location.  There's also a really great community of junior faculty as well as young people in the area (many of whom went to Colgate, then continued to hang out).  Colgate is also very good for families.
cons:
Colgate is at the leading edge of every bad trend in higher education, and brainless trend-following is at the top of the list!  The curriculum is being dumbed-down and grade-inflation (and work-deflation) is rampant because the target student for admittance is wealthy, whiny, and helicopter-parented.  Colgate builds its brand as being a sports & party-school conduit to high paying jobs you'll get through connections, not because of anything you learn in the classroom, and resource allocations reflect this, and the management desires only the double-down on these aspects, hastening the school's descent in the rankings (even while it tries to "game the system" of rankings with absurdities such as enforcing enrollment caps only the semester when US New & World Report is "counting").

Another con is for people who come to Colgate without families, ironically.  The structure of health insurance, as well as the child-tuition benefit, and even a mortgage assistance program all provide big bonuses to people with lots of kids and who are ready and financially able to buy a house in short order (before tenure review).  Even the structuring of campus activities and focus on the family in terms of child-care and fringe benefits makes clear that the university's preferred employees are those with a stay-at-home spouse and big families.  There are lots of reasons why this is in the university's interests, of course, but it sends a clear message about which employees are valued and which are expendable.

A related difficulty is that depending on what your partner's work and training is, it can be nearly impossible for the local economy to provide meaningful employment to a "trailing spouse".  This is particularly true if that partner has anything to do with academia, either in a teaching or any other capacity.  While the school pays lip-service to the idea that it wants to "help" new faculty's partners find meaningful employment, this is a huge hypocrisy which clothes a "willingness" to exploit highly-trained and -effective people far below their value, along with the implied affront that such partners should be grateful to have any position at Colgate it all, since the institution is practically God's gift.

In fact, lip-service and hypocrisy suffuses every part of this institution, which is increasingly run according to externally imposed "best-practices" with little attention to the views of the faculty.

job_title: Visiting Instructor/Assistant Professor in Hamilton, NY
pros: Excellent work environment plus the opportunities to work closely with smart and engaged students. There is a notable seriousness with which the educators at the College facilitate faculty development and student engagement opportunities.
cons: The location. The college is located in a rural area, and may take a little getting used to, especially for someone accustomed to city life. One has to travel fairly long distances to get to the nearest major city. Certainly, the good quality of life on campus - lectures, talks, etc., - compensates for this.

pros: I was able to develop an excellent relationship with my faculty advisor while also developing my skills as a researcher, such as learning EEG-related techniques, how to code in Matlab, and how to interact with participants.
cons: Colgate University is very remote. It is located in central New York, about five and half hours from New York City. As a result, it can feel very isolated to work here.

pros: Beautiful place to work. Opportunities for continued education (if you have a flexible work day schedule). Good stepping stone for young professionals who want to make a career of higher education.
cons:
Opportunity to grow professionally is discussed at length during the hiring process only to be sorely lacking over the course of several years. Working for such a small institution requires that individual employees have large amounts of responsibilities in very specific areas. As such, there is little catalyst for mid-level management to provide opportunities for your growth in new areas because there are not enough people to delegate responsibilities to. In order for you to learn/grow, you have to do it on your own, private time. This time is not compensated.

A culture of doing more than double the work that you are compensated for has become the norm. In order to receive a significant raise, promotion, or title change, you have to do the work of others for over a year before being recognized. Sometimes, you are not recognized for this work at all. Many mid-level employees have double and triple job titles as the only way they can hope to advance is to take on more and more work. Colgate benefits from this culture financially as instead of hiring three directors for very different roles, they can hire one over-worked, under-paid director instead.

By "significant raise" I mean 2%. Incredibly slow growth makes it difficult for the institution to maintain a work force for entry level positions. Young people are taken advantage of regularly by a system that is operating at a cut-throat level of business usually reserved for Wall Street financiers. The difference is that a finance company will fire you for not performing. Colgate will burn you out until you are finally smart enough to move on.

pros: There is a great family atmosphere, great benefits, and honestly, wonderful faculty. There is always something going on whether its a guest speaker, concert, craft project or BBQ!
cons: The pay scale is a bit on the low side, there also tends to be a lack of communication and this causes morale to easily slip, if you are an AA, there is a real lack of advancement opportunities.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Hamilton, NY
pros: The staff are incredibly friendly and understanding. They take an active interest in the student's coursework and life at Colgate, and are very flexible when it comes to shuffling your shifts around to accommodate a student's other commitments.
cons: There is really nothing bad about working at the Library. During midterms and finals it is easy to get blindsided with activity during what would be an otherwise quite shift, but that's about it.

review_title: It was good for learning, but a terrible work experience, and I could have saved a few years had I not worked there.
pros: Small community, reasonably well funded departments, challenging work environment at times, jobs tend to be easy, good employee benefits.
cons: Astonishing deficiencies in values and professionalism often cause unbridled problems across staff, faculty and student body issues at this organization. While at a surface and sub-cutaneous levels it functions well as an organization, at slightly deeper levels Colgate faces significant and unprecedented issues with how it struggles to treat its employees, students and community in a fair, consistent and sensible manner.

pros: working as a research assistant at Colgate puts you in a good position for job applications come graduation.  Pay is also quite good, especially during the summer.  It also allows you to foster a closer relationship with a faculty member, which can be helpful academically and professionally.
cons: It can be difficult to find a position if your grades aren't very good.  Additionally, most research positions only allow 10 hours/week of work.  Lastly, hours can be restricted based on supervision.

pros: Very reasonable when classes are scheduled during research, professor was laid back so missing days here and there wasn't necessarily a big deal. Also small school so heavy interaction with professors.
cons: Very low pay and stipends, definitely cannot cover the price of the education with student employment. Also got too busy with a variety of other classes, so was forced to stop and focus on grades.

review_title: Great benefits and vast university resources, little staff recognition
pros: Great benefits. Depending on your area of campus you could have extensive financial and university resources to complete your work. Independence with self-managing tasks
cons: Staff are an after thought, base pay was very low considering the wealth of the university and the cost of attendance.

pros: Learned a lot about Political Science, conducting research directly under a Professor.  Commitment varied from 4 to 6 hours per week, and tasks included compiling outlines of notes as well as organizing research materials from various library consortiums.
cons: The professor himself seemed disorganized, so sometimes it was difficult to gage what kind of work he was looking for.

pros: It was very meaningful. I had fun working for ResLife. I made a lot of friends in my staff. I learned a lot about myself.
cons: The department was disorganized. They were very inefficient and there are a lot of room for improvement. My job could have been made much easier if the department was more competent.

pros: Its an amazing atmosphere. If you can get a project that you are really passionate about it is 100% worth the time.
cons: Most of the time you'll have to live in Hamilton over the summer to get a position that pays you to do research. You might have to sacrifice an internship somewhere else to do research here.

pros:
Staff salaries are competitive for the area.
Salaries for faculty are very good.
Benefits are good but are currently under financial pressure to balance cost versus benefit to the university.
cons: Salaries for mid-level non-academic positions are competitive for the area but have not kept pace with inflation in recent years.

pros: Worked for a professor over the summer. The pay was decent and the schedule was flexible.
cons: Location was not so nice. Most of the places in town were closed over the summer.
